texts.shortText: Medium-sized crab, carapace (hard upper shell) crimson red, often mottled covered with short, dense yellowish or brownish hair (setae), with some longer hair towards the edges of carapace and chelipeds (pincers), legs. Carapace longer than wide, frontal margin with three projections (though only two are visible from dorsal view). Anterolateral margin (front corner) indented at the branchial groove, with no projection behind indent. The fifth leg is much longer than the fourth and is bent upwards.
Up to 36 mm in length, 32 mm in width.

Global: Endemic.

Local/Regional: From Saldanha Bay to East London.

This species is almost completely encased in a ball-shaped ascidian cloak. It is commonly found on sea fans, which it likely consumes.

It is though that the ascidian offers protection (often through chemical defense) and camouflage. These animals often exhibit nocturnal habits, though they are also frequently encountered during the day.
Likely consumes sea fans, which it is often encountered on.

Not specifically known for this species, but generally for this group sexes are separate, with females storing sperm in chitin-lined spermathecae, though this is not retained after moulting. Very little is known regarding reproduction of the group, though sperm and eggs meet externally in an abdominal chamber. Ovigerous females carry eggs below the abdomen until the larvae hatch.

This species is somewhat similar to the Cloaked sponge crab (Platydromia spongiosa), though P. latens can almost fully retract into the ascidian it carries on its back. Moreover, P. spongiosa has broader limbs and a rostrum ending in a single projection, as opposed to slender limbs and a rostrum with two projections.
